Hi all, I’m posting a review on an a day trip we booked through viator where we visited Pompeii and Positano.
If you’re not interested, scroll along because this is detailed but I hope it helps people in figuring out whether this would be worth it for them.
- We booked a day trip from Rome to Pompeii and Positano (along Amalfi coast) with Viator, operated through City Wonders. You are on a coach bus with about 32 people total. The first stop is Cassini which is about an hour and a half from Rome, for a 15 minute pit stop.
- Next stop is Pompeii, which is about 1 hr 30 min from Cassino, depending on traffic. Once there, you meet up with a separate tour guide that will walk you through the ruins, this was about 1.5 hr tour (did not cover ALL of pompeii). We had lunch at a restaurant in Pompeii but we opted to take our food on the bus so we could buy some souvenirs just outside the archaeological site as you do not have time before or after to browse.
- Next stop is Positano, which took us about an hour to get to because of traffic. When you’re about 3/4 of the way there you switch over to a van since the roads are even narrower in Positano. We spent about an hour and 45 minutes there including the walk to and from where they parked the van. That gave us some time to dip our feet in the sea and do some shopping.
- After that we had a 2.5 ish hour drive back to the first pit stop for a break, about 20-25 minutes. Then, we rode the rest of the way back to Rome, about 1-1.5 hr.
- It was a LONG day but it was worth it as we have limited time in Italy. In total it was about a 13 ish hour day from pickup to drop off. My husband would have liked to stay in Pompeii to explore more but that wasn’t an option 🤣
Hope this helps!

As regards transportation from Venice airport to Venice:

The cheapest option is ACTV urban bus line 5 at 10€ one way, 18€ return. There is a ticket office in the arrivals area, and a ticket machine at the bus stop right outside the terminal. Buses run every 15 minutes and the ride to the Piazzale Roma bus terminal takes about 25 minutes.

There are also coaches operated by another company (ATVO), which run every 30 minutes and are marginally faster. The tickets cost the same, but they are not interchangeable
with the urban bus tickets. I’m pointing this out because I’ve frequently seen tourists get on the wrong bus and get fined for not having a valid ticket. It’s easy to tell them apart, however: ACTV operates white urban buses, ATVO operates blue long-distance coaches.

For a more scenic ride into town, take the Alilaguna waterbus. Tickets are 15€ one way, 27€ return, and are sold at the ticket office in the arrivals hall. Take the moving walkway on the first floor to reach the docks. It’s a slower ride, but arguably quite unique, and it has the advantage of stopping at various points of the city including St. Mark’s.

The fastest and most expensive option is the water taxi, which typically costs 135€ for up to four people (with an additional 10€ for every additional person, up to a maximum of 10 people). Depending on where your accommodation is, it’ll take anywhere between 20 and 30 minutes. You can book one at one of the booths in the arrivals hall.

text:
A few days in Florence...
... breath officially taken!

The Duomo is just absolutely mind bogglingly beautiful, just incredible, the highlight of the trip for sure!

Uffizi Gallery needs a day dedicating to it really, it has a vast collection.

Boboli Gardens is lovely, I'd recommend picnicking there (very family friendly spot☺️, lots of space for children to play)

Head over to Babae to order a glass of delicious vino from one of the famous wine Windows 🍷

If you're a history/art buff (as I am) you'll be in your absolute element- every turn & every corner of the city is truly magnificent.

I don't mind admiting I cried at parts as it was just more than I ever imagined it could be, it's been on my Italian bucket list for years and I had a little wobble on the plane over worrying if I'd built it up in my head too much and got worried I'd be disappointed but it was all amazing!

I'd recommend pre-booking tickets for all the things you really want to see as we overheard that the tour of the dome was booked up for 10 days!

Luckily we hadn't planned on doing that this trip, we were lucky and got some last minute tickets for the tower.

I pre-booked Uffizi a week in advance and even then it was quite tight on time slots.

There's lots and lots to do that doesn't require tickets but be prepared for long queues and large crowds for the "free" attractions.

As with any tourist areas keep your belongings safe and gentlemen keep your hands in your front pockets on your phone/wallet and ladies wear a cross shoulder bag that does up securely ☺️

On a whole I felt extremely safe in Florence and there was a large police presence near all the main attractions.

As it was just me & my husband this trip I'm already planning another trip back with our little girls later this summer, it was just wonderful.

Enjoy it all when you go ☺️
